qas.question: A blockade of what coastline was ordered by the French government at the start of the war?
The small North German navy had how many ironclads at their disposal?
What was the name of the only turret ship that was able to conduct operations?
How many ships was the French navy able to dispatch to sea?
In pursuing Prussian ships, what resource was quickly depleted?

context: When the war began, the French government ordered a blockade of the <a0_0>North German coasts<a0_0/>, which the small North German navy (Norddeutsche Bundesmarine) with <a1_0>only five<a1_0/> ironclads could do little to oppose. For most of the war, the three largest German ironclads were out of service with engine troubles; only the turret ship <a2_0>SMS Arminius<a2_0/> was available to conduct operations. By the time engine repairs had been completed, the French fleet had already departed. The blockade proved only partially successful due to crucial oversights by the planners in Paris. Reservists that were supposed to be at the ready in case of war, were working in the Newfoundland fisheries or in Scotland. Only part of the <a3_0>470<a3_0/>-ship French Navy put to sea on 24 July. Before long, the French navy ran short of coal, needing 200 short tons (180 t) per day and having a bunker capacity in the fleet of only 250 short tons (230 t). A blockade of Wilhelmshaven failed and conflicting orders about operations in the Baltic Sea or a return to France, made the French naval efforts futile. Spotting a blockade-runner became unwelcome because of the question du charbon; pursuit of Prussian ships quickly depleted the <a4_0>coal reserves<a4_0/> of the French ships.
